member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the MapPixelToCoords function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapPixelToCoords(point, target.GetView());

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates This function finds the 2D position that matches the given pixel of the render-target. In other words, it does the inverse of what the graphics card does, to find the initial position of a rendered pixel. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (10, 50) in your render-target may map to the point (150, 75) in your 2D world -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). For render-windows, this function is typically used to find which point (or object) is located below the mouse cursor. This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2F)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the mapCoordsToPixel function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapCoordsToPixel(point, target.GetView());
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2F,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates This function finds the pixel of the render-target that matches the given 2D point. In other words, it goes through the same process as the graphics card, to compute the final position of a rendered point. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (150, 75) in your 2D world may map to the pixel (10, 50) of your render-target -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.PushGlStates
member.summary: Save the current OpenGL render states and matrices. This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering. Combined with PopGLStates, it ensures that: \li SFML's internal states are not messed up by your OpenGL code \li your OpenGL states are not modified by a call to a SFML function More specifically, it must be used around code that calls Draw functions. Example: // OpenGL code here... window.PushGLStates(); window.Draw(...); window.Draw(...); window.PopGLStates(); // OpenGL code here... Note that this function is quite expensive: it saves all the possible OpenGL states and matrices, even the ones you don't care about. Therefore it should be used wisely. It is provided for convenience, but the best results will be achieved if you handle OpenGL states yourself (because you know which states have really changed, and need to be saved and restored). Take a look at the ResetGLStates function if you do so.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.PopGlStates
member.summary: Restore the previously saved OpenGL render states and matrices. See the description of PushGLStates to get a detailed description of these functions.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.IRenderTarget.ResetGlStates
T:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.PrimitiveType
member.summary: Types of primitives that a VertexArray can render. Points and lines have no area, therefore their thickness will always be 1 pixel, regardless the current transform and view.

members.member: List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line
List of connected triangles, a point uses the two previous points to form a triangle
List of connected triangles, a point uses the common center and the previous point to form a triangle
List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line
List of connected triangles, a point uses the two previous points to form a triangle
List of connected triangles, a point uses the common center and the previous point to form a triangle

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderTexture.GenerateMipmap
member.summary: Generate a mipmap using the current texture data
member.remarks: This function is similar to and operates on the texture used as the target for drawing. Be aware that any draw operation may modify the base level image data. For this reason, calling this function only makes sense after all drawing is completed and display has been called. Not calling display after subsequent drawing will lead to undefined behavior if a mipmap had been previously generated.
member.returns: True if mipmap generation was successful, false if unsuccessful

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the MapPixelToCoords function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapPixelToCoords(point, target.GetView());

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.MapPixelToCoords(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2I,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from target coordinates to world coordinates This function finds the 2D position that matches the given pixel of the render-target. In other words, it does the inverse of what the graphics card does, to find the initial position of a rendered pixel. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (10, 50) in your render-target may map to the point (150, 75) in your 2D world -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). For render-windows, this function is typically used to find which point (or object) is located below the mouse cursor. This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2F)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates, using the current view This function is an overload of the mapCoordsToPixel function that implicitly uses the current view. It is equivalent to: target.MapCoordsToPixel(point, target.GetView());
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.MapCoordsToPixel(Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2F,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.View)
member.summary: Convert a point from world coordinates to target coordinates This function finds the pixel of the render-target that matches the given 2D point. In other words, it goes through the same process as the graphics card, to compute the final position of a rendered point. Initially, both coordinate systems (world units and target pixels) match perfectly. But if you define a custom view or resize your render-target, this assertion is not true anymore, ie. a point located at (150, 75) in your 2D world may map to the pixel (10, 50) of your render-target -- if the view is translated by (140, 25). This version uses a custom view for calculations, see the other overload of the function if you want to use the current view of the render-target.
member.param: The view to use for converting the point
member.returns: The converted point, in target coordinates (pixels)

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.PushGlStates
member.summary: Save the current OpenGL render states and matrices.

remarks.para: This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering. Combined with PopGLStates, it ensures that:
SFML's internal states are not messed up by your OpenGL code
Your OpenGL states are not modified by a call to a SFML function
More specifically, it must be used around code that calls Draw functions.

Note that this function is quite expensive: it saves all the possible OpenGL states and matrices, even the ones you don't care about. Therefore it should be used wisely. It is provided for convenience, but the best results will be achieved if you handle OpenGL states yourself (because you know which states have really changed, and need to be saved and restored). Take a look at the function if you do so.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.PopGlStates
member.summary: Restore the previously saved OpenGL render states and matrices. See the description of to get a detailed description of these functions.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.RenderWindow.ResetGlStates
member.summary: Reset the internal OpenGL states so that the target is ready for drawing.
member.remarks: This function can be used when you mix SFML drawing and direct OpenGL rendering, if you choose not to use PushGLStates/PopGLStates. It makes sure that all OpenGL states needed by SFML are set, so that subsequent Draw() calls will work as expected.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Load the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders from files
member.remarks: This function loads the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders. Pass NULL if you don't want to load a specific shader. The sources must be text files containing valid shaders in GLSL language. GLSL is a C-like language dedicated to OpenGL shaders; you'll probably need to read a good documentation for it before writing your own shaders.
member.param: Path of the vertex shader file to load, or null to skip this shader
Path of the geometry shader file to load, or null to skip this shader
Path of the fragment shader file to load, or null to skip this shader

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Load the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders from custom streams
member.remarks: This function loads the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders. Pass NULL if you don't want to load a specific shader. The sources must be valid shaders in GLSL language. GLSL is a C-like language dedicated to OpenGL shaders; you'll probably need to read a good documentation for it before writing your own shaders.
member.param: Source stream to read the vertex shader from, or null to skip this shader
Source stream to read the geometry shader from, or null to skip this shader
Source stream to read the fragment shader from, or null to skip this shader

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.NativeHandle
member.summary: Get the underlying OpenGL handle of the shader.
member.remarks: You shouldn't need to use this handle, unless you have very specific stuff to implement that SFML doesn't support.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.IsAvailable
member.summary: Tell whether or not the system supports shaders.
member.remarks: This property should always be checked before using the shader features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use Shader will fail.

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.IsGeometryAvailable
member.summary: Tell whether or not the system supports geometry shaders.

remarks.para: This property should always be checked before using the geometry shader features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use geometry shader features will fail.
Note: The first call to this function, whether by your code or SFML will result in a context switch.

member.remarks: This function loads the vertex, geometry and fragment shaders. Pass NULL if you don't want to load a specific shader. The sources must be valid shaders in GLSL language. GLSL is a C-like language dedicated to OpenGL shaders; you'll probably need to read a good documentation for it before writing your own shaders.
member.param: String containing the source code of the vertex shader
String containing the source code of the geometry shader
String containing the source code of the fragment shader

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.SetUniform(System.String,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Texture)
member.summary: Specify a texture as sampler2D uniform

remarks.para: name is the name of the variable to change in the shader. The corresponding parameter in the shader must be a 2D texture (sampler2D GLSL type).

Example:
uniform sampler2D the_texture; // this is the variable in the shader
sf::Texture texture; ... shader.setUniform("the_texture", texture);
It is important to note that must remain alive as long as the shader uses it, no copy is made internally.

To use the texture of the object being drawn, which cannot be known in advance, you can pass the special value Shader.CurrentTexture:
shader.setUniform("the_texture", Shader.CurrentTexture);

member.param: Name of the texture in the shader

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.SetUniform(System.String,Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shader.CurrentTextureType)
member.summary: Specify current texture as \p sampler2D uniform

remarks.para: This overload maps a shader texture variable to the texture of the object being drawn, which cannot be known in advance. The second argument must be . The corresponding parameter in the shader must be a 2D texture (sampler2D GLSL type).

member.param: Name of the texture in the shader

member.summary: Get the total number of points of the shape

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shape.GetPoint(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Get the position of a point The returned point is in local coordinates, that is, the shape's transforms (position, rotation, scale) are not taken into account. The result is undefined if index is out of the valid range.
member.param: Index of the point to get, in range [0 .. PointCount - 1]

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shape.GetLocalBounds
member.summary: Get the local bounding rectangle of the entity. The returned rectangle is in local coordinates, which means that it ignores the transformations (translation, rotation, scale, ...) that are applied to the entity. In other words, this function returns the bounds of the entity in the entity's coordinate system.
member.returns: Local bounding rectangle of the entity

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Shape.GetGlobalBounds
member.summary: Get the global bounding rectangle of the entity. The returned rectangle is in global coordinates, which means that it takes in account the transformations (translation, rotation, scale, ...) that are applied to the entity. In other words, this function returns the bounds of the sprite in the global 2D world's coordinate system.
member.returns: Global bounding rectangle of the entity

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Texture.Smooth
member.summary: Control the smooth filter

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Texture.Srgb
member.summary: Enable or disable conversion from sRGB

remarks.para: When providing texture data from an image file or memory, it can either be stored in a linear color space or an sRGB color space. Most digital images account for gamma correction already, so they would need to be "uncorrected" back to linear color space before being processed by the hardware. The hardware can automatically convert it from the sRGB color space to a linear color space when it gets sampled. When the rendered image gets output to the final framebuffer, it gets converted back to sRGB.
After enabling or disabling sRGB conversion, make sure to reload the texture data in order for the setting to take effect.
This option is only useful in conjunction with an sRGB capable framebuffer. This can be requested during window creation.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Texture.GenerateMipmap
member.summary: Generate a mipmap using the current texture data

remarks.para: Mipmaps are pre-computed chains of optimized textures. Each level of texture in a mipmap is generated by halving each of the previous level's dimensions. This is done until the final level has the size of 1x1. The textures generated in this process may make use of more advanced filters which might improve the visual quality of textures when they are applied to objects much smaller than they are. This is known as minification. Because fewer texels (texture elements) have to be sampled from when heavily minified, usage of mipmaps can also improve rendering performance in certain scenarios.

Mipmap generation relies on the necessary OpenGL extension being available. If it is unavailable or generation fails due to another reason, this function will return false. Mipmap data is only valid from the time it is generated until the next time the base level image is modified, at which point this function will have to be called again to regenerate it.

member.returns: True if mipmap generation was successful, false if unsuccessful

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Transformable
member.summary: Decomposed transform defined by a position, a rotation and a scale
member.remarks: A note on coordinates and undistorted rendering: By default, SFML (or more exactly, OpenGL) may interpolate drawable objects such as sprites or texts when rendering. While this allows transitions like slow movements or rotations to appear smoothly, it can lead to unwanted results in some cases, for example blurred or distorted objects. In order to render a SFML.Graphics.Drawable object pixel-perfectly, make sure the involved coordinates allow a 1:1 mapping of pixels in the window to texels (pixels in the texture). More specifically, this means: * The object's position, origin and scale have no fractional part * The object's and the view's rotation are a multiple of 90 degrees * The view's center and size have no fractional part

member.name: P:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Available
member.summary: Whether or not the system supports vertex buffers This function should always be called before using the vertex buffer features. If it returns false, then any attempt to use sf::VertexBuffer will fail.

member.name: T:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.UsageSpecifier
member.summary: Usage specifiers If data is going to be updated once or more every frame, set the usage to Stream. If data is going to be set once and used for a long time without being modified, set the usage to Static. For everything else Dynamic should be a good compromise.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Vertex[],System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices offset is specified as the number of vertices to skip from the beginning of the buffer. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated. If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails. No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer
Offset in the buffer to copy to

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Vertex[])
member.summary: Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices assuming an offset of 0 and a vertex count the length of the passed array. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated. If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails. No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.VertexBuffer.Update(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Graphics.Vertex[],System.UInt32)
member.summary: Update a part of the buffer from an array of vertices assuming a vertex count the length of the passed array. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is equal to the size of the currently created buffer, its whole contents are replaced. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, a new buffer is created containing the vertex data. If offset is 0 and vertexCount is less than the size of the currently created buffer, only the corresponding region is updated. If offset is not 0 and offset + vertexCount is greater than the size of the currently created buffer, the update fails. No additional check is performed on the size of the vertex array, passing invalid arguments will lead to undefined behavior.
member.param: Array of vertices to copy to the buffer
Offset in the buffer to copy to

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Cursor.#ctor(Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Cursor.CursorType)
member.summary: Create a native system cursor Refer to the list of cursor available on each system (see CursorType) to know whether a given cursor is expected to load successfully or is not supported by the operating system.

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Cursor.#ctor(System.Byte[],Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2U,Alis.Core.Aspect.Math.Vector.Vector2U)
member.summary: Create a cursor with the provided image Pixels must be an array of width by height pixels in 32-bit RGBA format. If not, this will cause undefined behavior. If pixels is null or either width or height are 0, the current cursor is left unchanged and the function will return false. In addition to specifying the pixel data, you can also specify the location of the hotspot of the cursor. The hotspot is the pixel coordinate within the cursor image which will be located exactly where the mouse pointer position is. Any mouse actions that are performed will return the window/screen location of the hotspot. Warning: On Unix, the pixels are mapped into a monochrome bitmap: pixels with an alpha channel to 0 are transparent, black if the RGB channel are close to zero, and white otherwise.
member.param: Array of pixels of the image
Width and height of the image

member.summary: Give access to the real-time state of the joysticks

member.summary: Maximum number of supported joysticks

member.name: F:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Joystick.ButtonCount
member.summary: Maximum number of supported buttons

member.summary: Maximum number of supported axes

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Joystick.IsConnected(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Check if a joystick is connected
member.param: Index of the joystick to check
member.returns: True if the joystick is connected, false otherwise

members.member:
Return the number of buttons supported by a joystick
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns 0. Index of the joystick Number of buttons supported by the joystick

Check if a joystick supports a given axis
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns false. Index of the joystick Axis to check True if the joystick supports the axis, false otherwise

Check if a joystick button is pressed
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns false. Index of the joystick Button to check True if the button is pressed, false otherwise

Get the current position of a joystick axis
If the joystick is not connected, this function returns 0. Index of the joystick Axis to check Current position of the axis, in range [-100 .. 100]

Update the states of all joysticks
This function is used internally by SFML, so you normally don't have to call it explicitly. However, you may need to call it if you have no window yet (or no window at all): in this case the joysticks states are not updated automatically.

Get the current position of the mouse

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Window.SetMouseCursorGrabbed(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Grab or release the mouse cursor
member.param: True to grab, false to release
member.remarks: If set, grabs the mouse cursor inside this window's client area so it may no longer be moved outside its bounds. Note that grabbing is only active while the window has focus and calling this function for fullscreen windows won't have any effect (fullscreen windows always grab the cursor).

member.param: True to enable v-sync, false to deactivate

member.name: M:Alis.Core.Graphic.SFML.Windows.Window.SetKeyRepeatEnabled(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enable or disable automatic key-repeat. Automatic key-repeat is enabled by default
member.param: True to enable, false to disable
